newsitem.title: CHINA: HK stocks set for rebound after Wall Street surge.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks set for rebound after Wall Street surge.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks look set for a rebound on Friday, with new records on Wall Street and continued strength in shares of HSBC Holdings Plc likely to wipe out Thursday's losses, brokers said.

"Today we are going to rebound, led by Hongkong Bank which was strong in London. Yesterday's selling in property stocks was a little bit overdone," said Antony Mak, sales director at Vickers Ballas. "We are likely to recover yesterday's losses."
The Hang Seng Index fell 141.05 points to 15,055.74 on Thursday, the first trading day under Chinese rule. Later, the Hang Seng London Reference Index rose 85.83 points to 15,141.57.
HSBC shares climed HK$3.15 in London trade to close at HK$241.15.

Kent Rossiter, institutional sales trader at Nikko Securities, said he expected the Hang Seng Index to trade in a range of 15,000 to 15,200 points. But he said property stocks could still see some weakness on Friday.
"In the short term there is going to be a little bit of pressure. There is going to be uncertainty until the government announces the details of its property measures," he said.
